title: 106_s1007
content: The Act may be cited as the "Great Ape Conservation Act of 1999". Great ape populations are declining, endangering their long-term survival in the wild. Chimpanzees, gorillas, bonobos, and orangutans are listed as endangered species. Conservation efforts are insufficient to address habitat loss and population decline due to human activities. Great apes serve as flagship species for conservation. Conservation of great apes is crucial for protecting tropical forest habitats and benefiting other wildlife species. Threats to great apes include habitat loss, population fragmentation, hunting, and live capture. They play a vital role in their ecosystems, and efforts to ensure their long-term viability require joint commitment from countries. The Great Ape Conservation Act aims to support conservation programs in countries where great apes are found and to maintain viable wild populations. This is essential for protecting tropical forest habitats and other wildlife species. The Great Ape Conservation Act aims to support conservation programs in countries where great apes are found and to maintain viable wild populations. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. The Act defines key terms such as "Administrator" as the head of the Agency for International Development, "CITES" as the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species, and "conservation" as methods to prevent the decline of wild species and activities related to wildlife management. The curr_chunk discusses various initiatives for conservation, including assistance in habitat management, enforcement of CITES and domestic laws, operation of sanctuaries, rehabilitation programs, conflict resolution, and community outreach and education. The curr_chunk defines key terms related to conservation efforts, including the Great Ape Conservation Fund, the definition of a great ape, and the role of the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 4. GREAT APE CONSERVATION ASSISTANCE. The Secretary will use funds from the Fund to provide financial assistance for great ape conservation projects approved by the Secretary. Project proposals can be submitted by wildlife management authorities, the CITES Secretariat, or individuals with expertise in great ape conservation. Project proposals for great ape conservation projects must include a concise statement of purposes, the responsible individual's name, qualifications of project conductors, project implementation methods, staff and community management, logistics, estimated funds and time needed, and evidence of project support. The project proposal must include evidence of support from governmental entities, details on matching funding, and any other information deemed necessary by the Secretary for project eligibility under this Act. The Secretary will review each proposal within 30 days of receipt and provide a copy to the Administrator. The Secretary will review project proposals to determine if they meet specified criteria. Within 180 days of receiving a proposal, the Secretary will consult with the Administrator, request comments from relevant countries, and approve or disapprove the proposal, notifying the submitter and countries involved. The Secretary may approve a project proposal under this section if it will enhance conservation programs for great apes by addressing conflicts, enhancing compliance with laws, and developing scientific information on habitat and population trends. The Secretary may approve conservation projects for great apes that focus on population numbers, habitat threats, and cooperative efforts among governments, communities, and organizations. Preference is given to projects that ensure long-term conservation and have matching funds available. Project recipients must submit periodic reports to the Secretary and Administrator for evaluation purposes. These reports, along with other project-related documents, must be made available to the public. Limitations on the use of grants under this Act include not using funds for captive breeding of great apes, except for breeding for release into the wild. SEC. 5. GREAT APE CONSERVATION FUND. Establishment of the "Great Ape Conservation Fund" in the Treasury's general fund, consisting of transferred amounts, appropriations, and interest earned. The Secretary of the Treasury can request necessary amounts for assistance, with a limit of 6 percent for administrative expenses. The "Great Ape Conservation Fund" in the Treasury's general fund allocates a percentage for administrative expenses each fiscal year. The Secretary of the Treasury is responsible for investing the remaining amount in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Investments can be made through original issue or purchase of outstanding obligations at market price, with the option to sell them at market price. The Secretary of the Treasury may sell the Fund at market price, with interest and proceeds from obligations credited to the Fund. Transfers to the Fund are made monthly based on estimates, with adjustments for accuracy. Donations can be accepted for assistance under section 4. Donations received by the Secretary are transferred to the Treasury for deposit into the Fund. Authorization of appropriations for the Fund is set at $5,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2000 to 2004.
